keyTakeAways: Bear attacks in Japan have increased sharply, with over 100 injuries and seven fatalities reported this year, the highest since 2006.
Billy Halloran, a 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears in the woods near Myoko, Japan, during a routine run.
The attack left Halloran with a broken arm and severe leg injuries, including a bite that removed a chunk of bone, requiring multiple surgeries and physical rehabilitation.
Experts attribute the rise in bear attacks to climate change disrupting traditional food sources, prompting bears to venture into urban and human-populated areas.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the surge in attacks.
Local residents use precautions like bear bells or loud music, and Halloran now considers carrying bear spray.
Halloran plans to return to running, supported by the local running community, though he acknowledges lasting psychological trauma from the incident.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, Billy Halloran, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears in the woods near Myoko, Japan, during a routine run. The bear attack, which left him with a broken arm and severe leg injuries requiring multiple surgeries, is part of a broader trend of rising bear attacks in Japan—over 100 people injured and seven killed this year, the highest since 2006. Experts attribute this surge to climate change disrupting bears’ traditional food sources, prompting them to venture into human-populated areas. In response, the Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations. Residents now use precautions like bear bells or loud music, and Halloran, despite trauma and ongoing recovery, remains determined to return to running in nature, supported by local communities.
title: Runner wrestles bear in the Japanese woods: ‘In one bite my arm was done’
